review_blob: Bomber. Pours with a thin white head that rests on top of a clear amber body. The aroma is sharp grapefruit with a faint floral hint. Flavor is resinous pine, bitter grapefruit, and sweeter pineapple. The beer is more balanced than expected, it isnt all about hop bitterness ("102 IBU 4 U"). A very solid beer.

Bomber. Pours much darker than I expected, looking like a strong iced tea. Held up to the light it reveals a slightly hazy deep copper color with an orange hue. The head is thin, white, and leaves minimal lacing on the side of the glass. The aroma is balanced between citrus hoppiness and caramel malt - again a surprise, as I expected the hop aroma to be dominant. The flavor is sweet caramel malt first, followed by a pleasant sticky bitterness, and lastly a fruity almost floral finish with a little malty nuttiness. Overall, an enjoyable beer with a surprising balance.

Bomber. Pours a jet black with a substantial caramel-colored head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt with hints of dark garden soil (really! - but in a good way). The alcohol is barely present in the nose. The flavor follows the aroma with chocolate, coffee, cigar smoke, and a touch of bourbon in the finish. The complexity of the beer makes it seem as if its been aged for months prior to bottling. A really enjoyable beer.

500 mL bottle dated Feb 3, 2009. A succulent citrus aroma bursts out of the bottle as soon as the cap is cracked. Pours a bright honey-gold color with a thin white head. Small bubbles can clearly be seen effervescing off the bottom of the glass. The aroma is all about juicy hops with grapefruit, pineapple, pine resin, and hints of grass.

The flavor is amazingly well balanced. The hops are prominent, of course, with an initial sweetness that is unexpected. Thats followed by a substantial bitterness that clings to the inside of the cheeks and then pleasantly subsides. All of the flavors are in harmony - making this a truly exceptional beer. Fantastic!

Bomber. Pours black with a dense one-finger latte-colored head. Holding the beer to a strong light reveals a ruby red interior. Enticing aromas of chocolate, coffee, dark roasted malt and light smoke. The taste is even better - lots of semi-sweet chocolate, dark roasted coffee and a hint of oak. A pleasant bitterness from the generous quantity of hops lingers on the tongue and balances the beer nicely. The body is moderately thick and smooth, with no detectable carbonation. This is a terrific porter - I enjoyed it from start to finish.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a very dark, almost black color with a thin tan head that quickly recedes to a small ring around the perimeter of the glass. Held up to a strong light, a dark ruby hue is exposed. The aroma is heavy on coffee, mocha, and roasted malt. Hints of vanilla and dark fruit are hidden in the background. The palate is dark roast coffee, chocolate, and heavily toasted malt. A delicious coffee flavor persists on the tongue, along with a slight bitterness on the back of the throat. This is a well done Baltic Porter - easy to drink and very enjoyable.
beer_name: Heater Allen Sandy Paws Baltic Porter (2008)

review_blob:
Bottle. Pours a golden honey color with a 2-finger white head. The head subsides to a thin layer that is soft and fluffy like cotton balls. The aroma is of bitter citrus (grapefruit) up front, that hides some sweeter fruit (pineapple?) in the background. There are also subtle hints of grass, hay, and pine in the aroma.

Flavor is intense with juicy hops and has a long-lasting bitterness that sticks to the inside of the cheeks. Fantastic beer that is easy to drink - a strong younger brother to the Pliny.

12 oz. can. What? This comes in a can? Yes, and it pours a thick black body with a small milk chocolate-colored head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, smoke, and dark malts. Taste is of dark chocolate, heavily roasted malts and lingering smoke. Lots of delicious flavors to hide the alcohol. This is a fantastic beer - pick one up when (if?) you find it, you wont be disappointed!

Bomber. Pours a nice coppery-orange color with a one-finger white head. Strong aroma of citrus, including grapefruit and pineapple. Flavor is smooth and sweet at first, with a good amount of malt to balance the large quantity of hops. Finish is slightly sticky and resinous, followed by delicious bitterness. Great IPA at a good price - would definitely buy again.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark ruby red color in the glass, not a jet black like many stouts. Aroma is of coffee, chicory, and light smoke. Taste is similar with a tickle of spice from the chicory. A good stout overall, but not particularly memorable.

2008 bomber in a pint glass. Pours with a one-finger off-white head that sticks to the upper third of the glass. The aroma is all hops - piney and floral with a juicy grapefruit bitterness. The sweetness of the caramel malt doesnt show its presence until you taste the beer, providing a nice balance to the strong bitterness of the hops. The mouthfeel is sticky, like light syrup. Be careful - the alcohol sneaks up on you quickly - it started going to my head only half-way through the first glass. This is an excellent beer - highly recommended.

2008 bottle. I received this beer as part of a 4-pack of Christmas-themed beers from Ridgeway. Because of the gimmicky nature of the package, my expectations werent high. Unfortunately, this beer couldnt even meet my low expectations. The beer touts itself as a brown ale, but was very pale - certainly not yellow, but a long way from having the robust color you might expect from a brown ale. The taste of the beer was also disappointing. There was nothing unique at all about this beer - it was thin, watery, and had no distinct flavors. Frankly, I did not enjoy this beer at all - I ended up pouring it down the sink. I hope the other beers in the box are better than this one.

2008 bomber. Pours very dark with a small head the color of milk chocolate. A ruby tinge can be seen around the rim, but only when the beer is held up to light. Aroma is heavy on oak smokiness, followed by sweet cherries, and then chocolate in the background. The vanilla aroma was subtle enough that it could barely be detected. The first sip is - SLAP - cherries! The initial swallow is a cherry cough syrup sweetness that quickly flashes off, followed next by dark chocolate, and then finishes a few long seconds later with the charred oak smokiness. The smoke taste lingers persistently on the inside of the cheeks. Overall, this is an excellent beer. I think a year in the cellar would make this beer truly fabulous - by mellowing the initial (almost artificial) cherry sweetness and bringing forth the chocolate in the finish. Ill have to pick up a couple more bottles for the cellar.

12 oz. bottle dated November 28, 2008. A strong bourbon aroma blasts from the bottle as soon as the cap is popped. Behind the bourbon are hints of chocolate, oak, vanilla, and alcohol (it is 13% ABV, after all).

The appearance is jet black with a creamy brown head and very little carbonation. No light is able to penetrate the beer, even around the rim.

The flavor of the bourbon is most prominent, followed by chocolate, molasses, smoke, vanilla, and oak. Some heat from the high ABV is evident as the beer flows down the throat. The mouthfeel is thick and syrupy and coats the inside of the cheeks - delicious!

I am amazed at the intensity of the bourbon flavors that are achieved after only 100 days in the barrel. This is a fantastic beer - I wish Id picked up a few more for the cellar.

22 oz. bomber. Initial aroma is pleasant with strong ginger tones and more subtle orange scent. Light copper color with a thin white head. There was more carbonation than I expected, though only a small head developed. Flavor is all ginger (duh!) and oranges - no malt. A little bitterness lingers for a short time, but then the palate is taken over by the ginger again.

I was interested in trying this beer, but found that I couldnt finish it. There is no balance between the ginger and malt - but maybe thats what the brewers intended - its all about ginger. The second half of the bottle went down the drain.
beer_name: Northwest Bad Panda Ginger Pale Ale

review_blob: 22 oz. bottle, 2008 vintage. Pours a beautiful ruby amber with light carbonation and nearly no head. Sweet aroma with hints of wood and apple cider. Good body - smooth and slightly thick, but not syrupy. The sweetness in the flavor is balanced by a dry hoppiness.
beer_name: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Tons of floral hop notes in the aroma. Nearly no head, just a ring of white bubbles around the perimeter of the glass. Appearance is clear with a lovely dark orange color. Long finish with a strong bitterness of grapefruit. Excellent IPA.

Great winter beer - probably the best winter seasonal from the Northwest breweries. Moderate head, minimal lacing, full body, great roasted malt aroma. 

Enjoy this beer on those cold winter nights when the wet snow is falling outside and you know youre going to have to get up in the morning and shovel it.

beer_brewer_name: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
review_blob: Batch #70. A chorus of very fine bubbles rushes to the top of the glass, forming a pillowy head about an inch thick. After a few minutes some of the head subsides leaving a surface that looks like small marshmallows floating on top the beer. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, and sweeter fruits (pineapple?). Color is very light amber, tending towards orange. Tastes sweet at first, followed by a light bitterness that is really enjoyable. Body is thin but full of flavor providing a good balance. Very enjoyable beer!
